Notes on elliptic curves.  II
By B.  J.  Birch at Manchester and H.  P.  F.  Smnnerton-Dyer at Cambridge
To Gina
§ 1.  Introduction
During the past six years,  we have made extensive calculations on cubic curves of the form
( 1.  1 ) Г : y ^ z = — Axz ^ — Bz ^
where В are rational integers.  In a previous paper [ 2 ], we have shown how ^ f,  the group of rational points on ( 1.  1 ), can conveniently be found on an electronic computer ; and we have given extensive tables.  In this and subsequent papers,  we put forward some conjectures connecting it with other more accessible quantities,  together with the nume rical evidence on which they are based. 
We begin this paper with a history of our investigations.  This may make the rest of the paper more understandable ; and it enables us to acknowledge the very considerable help we have obtained from other workers in this field. 
After the work of Siegel [ 19 ] on quadratic forms,  it is natural to look at the product
( 1.  2 ) HN.  Ip, 
where Np is the number of rational points on the curve defined by ( 1.  1 ) over the finite field of p elements.  Write for convenience
f ( P ) = П Npip over all p ^ P, 
In the autumn of 1958 we calculated,  for a number of curves ( 1.  1 ), the behaviour of /( P ) as jP increased.  It turned out that the rate of increase of f ( P ) was fairly closely correlated with the number of generators of infinite order of and there was some tendency for f ( P ) to be large when the generators of ^ ( or more precisely the correspond ing values of Xj y,  z ) were small.  We were in fact able to predict the number of generators of for specific curves 7 ^, with fairly consistent success,  by examining the values of f ( P ).
Since the behaviour oi f ( P ) as P oo is at least formally linked to the behaviour of CA ^) s == I ( see § 2 below ), we were led to make the two linked conjectures :
( A ) If g is the number of generators of ^ of infinite order ^ then f { P ) с ( log py as P -> oo,  and CA ^) ^ as s- > i ^ for some constants C,  C ' depending on Г, 
At this point we ran into difficulties.  The value of f ( P ) oscillates vigorously as P increases,  and there seems little hope of being able to find the constant С by this method
11 *
